turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: -- Fezzik, please --

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: Everybody ... MOVE!!

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Well, we Montoyas have never taken defeat easily. Come along, Fezzik. Bring the body.

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: The body?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Have you any money?

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: I have a little.

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: Inigo -- there's more than thirty --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: What's the difference?  We've got him. Help me here. We'll have to force feed him.

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: Has it been fifteen minutes?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: We can't wait -- the wedding's in half an hour and we must strike in the hustle and the bustle beforehand.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Tilt his head back. Open his mouth.

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: How long do we have to wait before we know if the miracle works?

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: You've been mostly dead all day.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: We had Miracle Max make a pill to bring you back.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Where did we put that wheelbarrow the Albino had?

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: Over the Albino, I think.

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: Will this do?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Where did you get that?

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: At Miracle Max's. It fit so nice, he said I could keep it.

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: Don't pester him, he's had a hard day.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Right, right, sorry.

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: Inigo.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: I hope we win...

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: He's getting away from me, Fezzik. Please. FEZZIK!

turns.speaker: FEZZIK
turns.text: I'll be right back.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: I brought you a special present.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Open it up.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: A book?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: That's right. When I was your age, television was called books. And this is a special book. It was the book my father used to read to me when I was sick, and I used to read it to your father. And today, I'm gonna read it to you.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Has it got any sports in it?

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: It doesn't sound too bad. I'll try and stay awake.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Oh. Well, thank you very much. It's very nice of you. Your vote of confidence is overwhelming. All right.  The Princess Bride, by S. Morgenstern. Chapter One. Buttercup was raised on a small farm in the country of Florin.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Her favorite pastimes were riding her horse and tormenting the farm boy that worked there. His name was Westley, but she never called him that.  Isn't that a wonderful beginning?

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Yeah. It's really good.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Nothing gave Buttercup as much pleasure as ordering Westley around.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: -hold it, hold it-

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: What is this? Are you trying to trick me? -- Where's the sports? -- Is this a kissing book?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: -- wait, just wait --

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: -- well, when does it get good?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Keep your shirt on. Let me read.  Westley had no money for marriage. So he packed his few belongings and left the farm to seek his fortune across the sea.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: It was a very emotional time for Buttercup --

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: I don't be-leeve this.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Westley didn't reach his destination. His ship was attacked by the Dread Pirate Roberts, who never left captives alive. When Buttercup got the news that Westley was murdered --

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: -- murdered by pirates is good --

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: The Eel doesn't get her. I'm explaining to you because you looked nervous.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Well, I wasn't nervous.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Well, maybe I was a little bit concerned. But that's not the same thing.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Because I can stop now if you want.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Oh no. No, please.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: They're kissing again, do we have to hear the kissing part?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Someday, you may not mind so much.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Skip on to the Fire Swamp -- that sounded good.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Oh. You're sick, I'll humor you.  So now, where were we here? Yeah, yeah, yeah. Ah. Oh. Okay. Westley and Buttercup raced along the ravine floor.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: You read that wrong. She doesn't marry Humperdinck, she marries Westley. I'm just sure of it. After all that Westley did for her, if she does not marry him, it wouldn't be fair.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Well, who says life is fair? Where is that written? Life isn't always fair.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: I'm telling you you're messing up the story, now get it right!

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Do you want me to go on with this?

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: All right, then. No more interruptions.  ... at noon, she met her subjects again. This time as their Queen.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: It was ten days till the wedding. The King still lived, but Buttercup's nightmares were growing steadily worse.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: See? Didn't I tell you she'd never marry that rotten Humperdinck?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: -- yes, you're very smart. Shut-Up.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Westley's only faking, right?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: You want me to read this or not?

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Who gets Humperdinck?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Who kills Prince Humperdinck? At the end, somebody's got to do it. Is it Inigo? Who?

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: No! I'm okay. I'm okay.  -- sit down. All right?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Okay.  All right, now, let's see. Where were we? Oh yes. In the Pit of Despair.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: What? What?

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: No, it's kissing again. You don't want to hear it.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: I don't mind so much.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: Now I think you ought to go to sleep.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: THE KID
turns.text: Maybe you could come over and read it again to me tomorrow.

turns.speaker: GRANDFATHER
turns.text: As you wish...

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Yellin.

turns.speaker: YELLIN
turns.text: Sire.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: As Chief Enforcer of all Florin, I trust you with this secret: killers from Guilder are infiltrating the Thieves' Forest and plan to murder my bride on our wedding night.

turns.speaker: YELLIN
turns.text: My spy network has heard no such news.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: She will not be murdered. On the day of the wedding, I want the Thieves' Forest emptied and every inhabitant arrested.

turns.speaker: YELLIN
turns.text: Many of the thieves will resist. My regular enforcers will be inadequate.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Form a Brute Squad then. I want the Thieves' Forest emptied before I wed.

turns.speaker: YELLIN
turns.text: It won't be easy, Sire.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Try ruling the world sometime.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Rise and report.

turns.speaker: YELLIN
turns.text: The Thieves' Forest is emptied. Thirty men guard the castle gate.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Double it. My Princess must be safe.

turns.speaker: YELLIN
turns.text: The gate has but one key, and I carry that.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: You mean you wish to surrender to me? Very well, I accept.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: I give you full marks for bravery --don't make yourself a fool.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: Ah, but how will you capture us? We know the secrets of the Fire Swamp. We can live there quite happily for some time. So, whenever you feel like dying, feel free to visit.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: I tell you once again -- surrender!

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: It will not happen!

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: For the last time -- SURRENDER!

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: DEATH FIRST!!

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: A technicality that will shortly be remedied. But first things first. To the death.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: No.  To the pain.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: I don't think I'm quite familiar with that phrase.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: I'll explain. And I'll use small words so that you'll be sure to understand, you wart-hog-faced buffoon.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: That may be the first time in my life a man has dared insult me.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: -- and then my tongue, I suppose. I killed you too quickly the last time, a mistake I don't mean to duplicate tonight.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: I wasn't finished -- the next thing you lose will be your left eye, followed by your right --

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: -- and then my ears, I understand. Let's get on with it

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: Wrong! Your ears you keep, and I'll tell you why --

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: There was a mighty duel -- it ranged all over. They were both masters.

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: Who won? How did it end?

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: The loser ran off alone.  The winner followed those footprints toward Guilder!

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: Shall we track them both?

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: The loser is nothing. -- Only the Princess matters --  -- clearly this was all planned by warriors of Guilder. We must be ready for whatever lies ahead. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                           42.

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: Could this be a trap?

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: I always think everything could be a trap -- Which is why I'm still alive.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Once we're out of sight, take him back to Florin and throw him in the Pit of Despair.

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: I swear it will be done.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: She's been like that ever since the Fire Swamp.  It's my father's failing health that's upsetting her.

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: I could never cause you grief; consider our wedding off.  You returned this Westley to his ship?

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Then we will simply alert him.  Beloved, are you certain he still wants you? After all, it was you who did the leaving in the Fire Swamp. Not to mention that pirates are not known to be men of their words.

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: Your Princess is really a winning creature. A trifle simple, perhaps, but her appeal is undeniable.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Oh, I know. The people are quite taken with her. It's odd, but when I hired Vizzini to have her murdered on our engagement day, I thought that was clever. But it's going to be so much more moving when I strangle her on our wedding night. Once Guilder is blamed, the nation will be truly outraged. They'll demand we go to war.

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: Now, where is that secret knot? It's impossible to find.  Are you coming down into the Pit? Westley's got his strength back. I am starting him on The Machine tonight.

turns.speaker: HUMPERDINCK
turns.text: Tyrone, you know how much I love watching you work. But, I've got my country's five hundredth anniversary to plan, my wedding to arrange, My wife to murder, and Guilder to frame for it. I'm swamped. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                           75.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Your guess is as good as mine --

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: I'll beat you both apart. I'll take you both together.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: Who are you? -- Are we enemies? Why am I on this wall? -- Where's Buttercup? --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Buttercup is marrying Humperdinck in a little less than half an hour, so all we have to do is get in, break up the wedding, steal the Princess, make our escape after I kill Count Rugen.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: That doesn't leave much time for dilly dallying.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: And it is guarded by sixty men.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: And our assets?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Your brains, Fezzik's strength, my steel.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: Well, why didn't you list that among our assets in the first place? What I wouldn't give for a holocaust cloak.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: There we cannot help you.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Why? You can't even lift one.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: True, but that's hardly common knowledge, is it?  Thank you. Now, there may be problems once we're inside.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I'll say -- how do I find the Count? -- Once I do, how do I find you again? -- Once I find you again, how do we escape? --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: Light him.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Where's Fezzik?

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: I thought he was with you.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: In that case --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: You know, it's very strange -- I have been in the revenge business so long, now that it's over, I don't know what to do with the rest of my life.

turns.speaker: WESTLEY
turns.text: Have you ever considered piracy? You'd make a wonderful Dread Pirate Roberts.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Hello. My name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die.

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: Stop saying that!

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: No --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: -- offer me money --

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: -- yes --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: -- power too -- promise me that --

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: -- all that I have and more please --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: -- offer me everything I ask for --

turns.speaker: RUGEN
turns.text: -- anything you want --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I WANT MY FATHER BACK, YOU SON- OFA-BITCH!

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: What? What?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Are you the Miracle Max who worked for the King all those years?

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: The King's stinking son fired me. And thank you so much for bringing up such a painful subject. While you're at it, why don't you give me a nice paper cut and pour lemon juice on it? We're closed!

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Look, I'm retired. And besides, why would you want someone the King's stinking son fired? I might kill whoever you wanted me to miracle.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: He's already dead.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: He is, eh? I'll take a look. Bring him in.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Sir. Sir.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Hah?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: We're really in a terrible rush.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Don't rush me, sonny. You rush a miracle man, you get rotten miracles. You got money?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Sixty-five.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Sheesh! I never worked for so little, except once, and that was a very noble cause. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                           93.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: This is noble, sir.  His wife is crippled. His children are on the brink of starvation.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Are you a rotten liar.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I need him to help avenge my father, murdered these twenty years.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Your first story was better.  Where's that bellows?  He probably owes you money, huh? Well, I'll ask him.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: He's dead. He can't talk.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Look who knows so much. Well, it just so happens that your friend here is only mostly dead. There's a big difference between mostly dead and all dead. Please open his mouth.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Now, mostly dead is slightly alive. Now, all dead...well, with all dead, there's usually only one thing that you can do.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: True love. You heard him. You could not ask for a more noble cause than that.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: Sonny, true love is the greatest thing in the world. Except for a nice MLT, a mutton, lettuce and tomato sandwich, where the mutton is nice and lean and the tomato is ripe. They're so perky, I love that. But that's not what he said. He distinctly said "to blave." And, as we all know, "to blave" means "to bluff." So you're probably playing cards, and he cheated

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Humiliations galore!

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: That is a noble cause. Give me the sixty-five, I'm on the job.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Thank you for everything.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Slow going?

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Look, I don't mean to be rude, but this is not as easy as it looks. So I'd appreciate it if you wouldn't distract me.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I do not suppose you could speed things up?

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: If you're in such a hurry, you could lower a rope, or a tree branch, or find something useful to do. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                           26.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I could do that. In fact, I've got some rope up here. But I do not think that you will accept my help, since I am only waiting around to kill you.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: That does put a damper on our relationship.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: But I promise I will not kill you until you reach the top.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: That's very comforting. But I'm afraid you'll just have to wait.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I hate waiting. I could give you my word as a Spaniard.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: No good. I've known too many Spaniards.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: You don't know any way you'll trust me?

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Nothing comes to mind.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: We'll wait until you're ready.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Again. Thank you.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Do you always begin conversations this way?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: My father was slaughtered by a sixfingered man. He was a great swordmaker, my father. And when the six-fingered man appeared and requested a special sword, my father took the job. He slaved a year before he was done.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: How old were you?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I was eleven years old. When I was strong enough, I dedicated my life to the study of fencing. So the next time we meet, I will not fail. I will go up to the sixfingered man and say, "Hello, my name is Inigo Montoya. You killed my father. Prepare to die."

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: You've done nothing but study swordplay?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: More pursuit than study lately. You see, I cannot find him. It's been twenty years now. I am starting to lose confidence. I just work for Vizzini to pay the bills. There's not a lot of money in revenge.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Well, I certainly hope you find him, someday.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: You are ready, then?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: You seem a decent fellow. I hate to kill you.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: You seem a decent fellow. I hate to die.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Begin!

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: I thought it fitting, considering the rocky terrain --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Naturally, you must expect me to attack with Capo Ferro.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: You are wonderful!

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Thank you -- I've worked hard to become so.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I admit it -- you are better than I am.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Then why are you smiling?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Because I know something you don't know.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: And what is that?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I am not left-handed.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: You're amazing!

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I ought to be after twenty years.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: There's something I ought to tell you.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: I am not left-handed either.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Who are you?!

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: No one of consequence.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I must know.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Get used to disappointment.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Kill me quickly.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: I would as soon destroy a stained glass window as an artist like yourself. However, since I can't have you following me either --

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Making sure nobody's following us.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: That would be inconceivable.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Stop doing that. We can all relax, it's almost over-

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: You're sure nobody's following us?

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: As I told you, it would be absolutely, totally, and in all other ways, inconceivable. No one in Guilder knows what we've done. And no one in Florin could have gotten here so fast. Out of curiosity, why do you ask?

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: No reason. It's only, I just happened to look behind us, and something is there.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Go in, get after her!

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Look! He's right on top of us. I wonder if he is using the same wind we are using.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: He's climbing the rope. And he's gaining on us.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Inconceivable!

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: He didn't fall? Inconceivable!!

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: You keep using that word -- I do not think it means what you think it means.  My God! He's climbing.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: I want to duel him left-handed.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: You know what a hurry we're in.

turns.speaker: INIGO
turns.text: Well, it's the only way I can be satisfied. If I use my right -- tch -- over too quickly.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Oh, have it your way.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Let me explain-

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: -- there's nothing to explain. You're trying to kidnap what I've rightfully stolen. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                           43.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Perhaps an arrangement can be reached.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: There will be no arrangement --  -- and you're killing her!

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: But if there can be no arrangement, then we are at an impasse.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: I'm afraid so -- I can't compete with you physically. And you're no match for my brains.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: You're that smart?

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Let me put it this way: have you ever heard of Plato, Aristotle, Socrates?

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Morons.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Really? In that case, I challenge you to a battle of wits.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: For the Princess?

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: I accept.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Good. Then pour the wine.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Inhale this, but do not touch.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: I smell nothing.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: What you do not smell is called iocane powder. It is odorless, tasteless, dissolves instantly in liquid, and is among the more deadlier poisons known to man.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Hmm.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Now, a clever man would put the poison into his own goblet, because he would know that only a great fool would reach for what he was given. I'm not a great fool, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you. But you must have known I was not a great fool; you would have counted on it, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: You've made your decision then7

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Not remotely. Because iocane comes from Australia, as everyone knows. And Australia is entirely peopled with criminals. And criminals are used to having people not trust them, as you are not trusted by me. So I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Truly, you have a dizzying intellect.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Wait till I get going! Where was I?

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Australia.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: Yes -- Australia, and you must have suspected I would have known the powder's origin, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me. ---------------------------------------------------------------------------                                                           46.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: You're just stalling now.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: You'd like to think that, wouldn't you?  You've beaten my giant, which means you're exceptionally strong. So, you could have put the poison in your own goblet, trusting on your strength to save you. So I can clearly not choose the wine in front of you. But, you've also bested my Spaniard which means you must have studied. And in studying, you must have learned that man is mortal so you would have put the poison as far from yourself as possible, so I can clearly not choose the wine in front of me.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: You're trying to trick me into giving away something -- it won't work --

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: It has worked -- you've given everything away -- I know where the poison is.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: Then make your choice.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: I will. And I choose --

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: What's so funny?

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: I'll tell you in a minute. First, let's drink -- me from my glass, and you from yours.

turns.speaker: MAN IN BLACK
turns.text: You guessed wrong.

turns.speaker: VIZZINI
turns.text: You only think I guessed wrong --  -- that's what's so funny! I switched glasses when your back was turned. You fool.

turns.speaker: MIRACLE MAX
turns.text: -- get back, witch --

turns.speaker: VALERIE
turns.text: I'm not a witch, I'm your wife. But after what you just said, I'm not even sure I want to be that anymore.
